review.title: Wavelet Scattering on the Pitch Spiral
review.abstract: We present a new representation of harmonic sounds that linearizes the dynamics of pitch and spectral envelope, while remaining stable to deformations in the time-frequency plane. It is an instance of the scattering transform, a generic operator which cascades wavelet convolutions and modulus nonlinearities. It is derived from the pitch spiral, in that convolutions are successively performed in time, log-frequency, and octave index. We give a closed-form approximation of spiral scattering coefficients for a nonstationary generalization of the harmonic source-filter model.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The spectral evolution of harmonic sounds conveys essential information about audio classification, blind source separation, transcription, and other processing tasks, but this information is difficult to capture in time-varying polyphonic mixtures. On the one hand, spectral pattern recognition algorithms [1] are subject to recognition errors because they impose severe limitations on the form of harmonic patterns. On the other, time-variable generalizations of matrix factorization [2] are suppressed and therefore cannot lead to a satisfactory solution. In this article, we address the characterization of harmonic structures without any recognition or training. Wavelets have long proven that they provide significant, sparse activations as long as they operate on a dimension where the signal already exhibits a certain regularity. Although a single sine wave traces a regular edge at the time-frequency level, a harmonic composition is formed from sharp sharp spikes.

sections.heading: 2. FROM TIME SCATTERING TO SPIRAL SCATTERING
sections.text: This section forms the spiral scattering transformation step by step as a cascade of wave transformations over time, protocol frequency and octave index. All three variables have the same frame.

sections.heading: 2.2. Joint time-frequency scattering
sections.text: The time scattering transformation defined in Equation (4) decomposes each frequency band individually and therefore cannot properly capture the coherence of time-frequency structures, such as those induced by pitch contour. To address this, Andén et al. [4] have redefined wave frequencies as functions of both time and log frequency, indexed by pairs λ2 = (α, β), where α is a modulation frequency in hertz and β is a frequency along the log frequencies in cycles per octave, defining the common wave frequencies as a function of the log frequency axis, i.e. along the chromes.

sections.heading: 2.3. Spiral scattering
sections.text: The frequency spiral defined in Equation (7) corresponds in its total height to the variability of pitch. However, it is not aware that the harmonic structure of spoken sounds, such as vowels or musical notes, in the multi-stage evolution of this structure yields relevant information about transients and formal changes that are almost independent of pitch. To capture this information, we extend the common time frequency to regularity in time in conjunction with regularity along adjacent constant Q bands. Just like the wave filter banks along time and the log frequency, we were defined in the two previous subsections by introducing a third wave filter bank. We roll the log frequency variably into a tone spiral that makes a complete rotation in each octave (see Figure 1).

sections.heading: 3. DEFORMATIONS OF THE SOURCE-FILTER MODEL
sections.text: A classic model for the production of spoken language consists in the folding of a harmonic glottal source e (t) with a voice tract filter h (t). The introduction of independent deformations in both components brings realistic variability in pitch and spectral envelope. This section examines the decomposition of the deformed source filter model in the spiral scatter transformation.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: The spiral model we have presented is well known in music theory and experimental psychology [5, 6, 7]. However, existing methods of audio signal processing do not fully exploit its richness because they represent pitches either on a line (e.g. MFCC) or on a circle (e.g. Chroma characteristics). In this article we have shown how spiral scattering can represent the transience of harmonic sounds.
